Description: Digital photograph (colour); detail of engraved, pecked rock art on rock surface, showing infilled figures of two ostriches and a bull, all upright. Bull is central, facing right with large c-curved horns and beard/dewlap. Leftmost ostrich superimposes/is superimposed by rump of bull, also faces right. Rightmost ostrich faces left, to upper right of bull’s horns. Karkur Talh, Sudan. Scanned
Curator's comments: See 2013,2034.354 for scale. Karkur Tahl is the largest wadi (dry seasonal riverbed valley) in the sandstone eastern section of Jebel Uweinat, a granite and sandstone massif on the border of Egypt, Libya and Sudan. Karkur Talh is around 25 km long and lies mostly in Sudan, but partly within Egypt’s borders. There is an abundance of both painted and engraved rock art in shelters in the smaller side wadis. The engravings were first revealed to academia by Ahmed Hassanein in 1923 and a few photographs published in his report on the journey in National Geographic in 1924. A more comprehensive publication of rock art sites in Karkur Talh was made by Prince Kemal el Dine with Abbe Breuil in 1925 following his discovery of a painted cave in Karkur Talh. Further exploration and publications were made by numerous others including renowned explorer Ralph Bagnold’s expedition in 1931, with further exploration from László Almásy and Leo Frobenius in 1933. The largest professional exploration of the massif to date was made in 1968 by a team of Belgian scientists.
Acquisition name: Donated by: Trust for African Rock Art
